step_by_step_thinking: The patient's symptoms of fluent speech, intact comprehension, and inability to repeat verbal tasks align with conduction aphasia. Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, which connects the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area) and superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area). While the inferior frontal and superior temporal gyri are involved, the critical structure impairing repetition is the arcuate fasciculus. Documents [1][3], and [13] support this, highlighting the arcuate fasciculus's role in repetition deficits.
